z:row.TitlePrimary: Production management software suitable for group work
z:row.TitleSecondary: Proceedings of 5th International Conference on Human-Computer Interaction, 8-13 Aug. 1993
z:row.TitleTertiary: Human-Computer Interaction. Proceedings of the Fifth International Conference on Human-Computer Interaction (HCI International '93)
z:row.Author_Address_Affiliation: Dept. of Syst. Planning, Fraunhofer Inst. for Prod. Syst. & Design Technol., Berlin, Germany
z:row.Abstract: Group work on shop floor level gains an increasing importance, because it enables better usage of capacities, mutual help in difficult situations and mutual learning support. Higher customer orientation causes more unpredicted situations that increasingly demand decentralized short term decision making. Principles of wholistic tasks, of flat hierarchies with distributed responsibilities and latest research about gaining and use of experience at shop floor level form an approach of cooperative an coordinated decision making. The task of scheduling is seen as a task that requires much joint decision making within a group, as well as a high degree of coordination with remote departments. The proposed approach postulates enhanced functionality of shop floor control software (SFC), hardware that enables joint decision making (whiteboard architecture) for groups and interacting networking software that allows to use company wide data and software applications of other departments
z:row.User2: production management software; group work; mutual learning support; decision making; flat hierarchies; shop floor control software; whiteboard architecture; networking software

z:row.TitlePrimary: LMFBR licensing and safety issues in the US
z:row.TitleSecondary: Proceedings of the L.M.F.B.R. Safety Topical Meeting, 19-23 July 1982
z:row.TitleTertiary: Proceedings of the L.M.F.B.R. Safety Topical Meeting
z:row.Author_Address_Affiliation: Univ. of Wisconsin, Madison, WI, USA
z:row.Abstract: Reviews the status of the LMFBR licensing in the US with particular attention given to the Clinch River Breeder Reactor (CRBR), discusses safety philosophy and criteria as viewed by the US Nuclear Regulatory Commission, addresses recent CRBR design changes which influence safety, and comments on studies and decisions currently being made for light water reactors (LWRs), which may influence LMFBR licensing. Finally, the author presents personal views on safety issues which he believes may assume new or added importance in the US if commercial-scale LMFBRs are deployed there
z:row.User2: LMFBR licensing; safety; Clinch River Breeder Reactor; US Nuclear Regulatory Commission

z:row.TitlePrimary: LMFBR LICENSING AND SAFETY ISSUES IN THE US
z:row.TitleSecondary: Proceedings of the LMFBR Safety Topical Meeting (Liquid Metal Fast Breeder Reactor).
z:row.Author_Address_Affiliation: Univ of Wisconsin, Madison, Wis, USA
z:row.Notes: Compilation and indexing terms, Copyright 2006 Elsevier Inc. All rights reserved
z:row.User2: SAFETY PHILOSOPHY AND CRITERIA; LIGHT WATER REACTORS; CLINCH RIVER BREEDER REACTOR; DESIGN CHANGES AFFECTING SAFETY; REQUIREMENTS FOR EMERGENCY RESPONSE; WASTE DISPOSAL FACILITIES

z:row.Publisher: ANS, La Grange Park, Ill, USA
z:row.Author_Address_Affiliation: Univ of Wisconsin-Madison, Madison, Wis, USA
z:row.Notes: Compilation and indexing terms, Copyright 2006 Elsevier Inc. All rights reserved

z:row.TitlePrimary: Multi-fluid modeling of annular two-phase flow
z:row.Keyword: fission reactor cooling and heat recovery|two-phase flow
z:row.Author_Address_Affiliation: Dept. of Nuclear Engng., Univ. of Wisconsin, Madison, WI, USA
z:row.Abstract: An extensive analytical investigation of annular two-phase flows has been conducted with a general mathematical formulation which is applicable to both adiabatic and boiling flows. The model can be applied to flows in both simple and complex geometries, and predicts the thermal-hydrodynamic characteristics of annular two-phase flows over a wide range of conditions with very good accuracy. The general model for formulation and comparisons of predictions of the model with air-water experimental data are given. Predictions of the model are compared with heat flux and other experimental data in round tubes, annuli, and rod arrays. The model is unique with respect to the completeness and range of applicability
z:row.User2: boiling flows; round tubes; annuli; rod arrays; annular two phase flow; multifluid modelling; thermal hydrodynamic characteristics; adiabatic annular flow

z:row.TitlePrimary: A review of spray-cooling and bottom-flooding work for LWR cores
z:row.Author_Address_Affiliation: Nuclear Engng. Dept., Univ. of Wisconsin, Madison, WI, USA
z:row.Abstract: Rewetting or the re-establishment of water films on the hot, fuel rod surfaces is of fundamental importance following a loss-of-coolant accident in a water cooled reactor. Two techniques are used: rewetting by a falling film of water (top spray) and rewetting by an upflow of water (bottom flooding). Considerable theoretical and experimental work has been done to investigate the effects of different operating parameters on these techniques, and that work is summarized
z:row.User2: LWR cores; water films; spray cooling; bottom flooding; rewetting; hot fuel rod surfaces; LOCA

z:row.TitlePrimary: Conceptual design of a Tokamak reactor
z:row.TitleSecondary: Texas Symposium on the Technology of Controlled Thermonuclear Fusion Experiments and the Engineering Aspects of Fusion Reactors. (Abstracts only received), 20-22 Nov. 1972
z:row.TitleTertiary: Texas Symposium on the Technology of Controlled Thermonuclear Fusion Experiments and the Engineering Aspects of Fusion Reactors. (Abstracts only received)
z:row.Abstract: A scoping design has been carried out to determine the technological problems associated with the low β Tokamak approach to reactors. This system is envisioned to operate quasi steady state producing about 1000 MW(th) using stainless steel and a wall loading of 0.85 MW/m2. Various system aspects of the design are described including the plasma and its control; a divertor and start-up magnet system; a blanket, shield and heat removal system; toroidal magnet design and limiting stress effects; and an analysis of system hazards
z:row.User2: conceptual design; Tokamak reactor; scoping design; plasma; control; divertor; blanket; shield; heat removal system; toroidal magnet; limiting stress effects; hazards; low beta Tokamak; quasi steady state operation
